page.title: 02EARTHWORKS, HARROW.
page.content: Stretching for 25 miles from Windsor to Potters Bar is an earthworks called {Grim's Dyke.}A section of this can be seen at Saddlers Mead in Hatch End. Dates for the building of this feature range from 500 B.C. It was probably built by{Saxon}tribes, perhaps the Catuvellauni tribe, as a defence line with a wooden fence or palisade on the top and a ditch filled with water behind it. It is mentioned as{Divels Dyke}in the Domesday Book when it was being used as an animal enclosure. Today, it has fallen away and is only 4 metres high at its highest point. It looks like a long bank with trees along it. {Grim}was probably another name for {Woden,}the Saxon god of thunder. Others think that{Grim}means{goblin}or {devil.}
